title: Supercharging Sales Teams Using AI Alexa Grabell, Co-Founder of Pocus | S11E2

and you laugh because what feels like
awful today is going to be like a funny

just does not matter
[Music]
today. Welcome to the room podcast. I'm
Claudia Lori, the founder, and I'm
Madison Makawain, the funer. We are on a
mission to open the door to the room
where it happens. Sharing the stories of
some of the world's most iconic
builders. Authentic storytelling is core
to our community. It all started as two
best friends who met in the heart of San
Francisco as product managers in 2018.
When I left Uber to start my company,
Madison was our first yes. It was these
conversations that birthed the room
podcast. And nearly 5 years later, our
guests have built businesses with a
combined enterprise value of over a
hundred billion. You'll recognize
conversations with your favorite
technology founders from Perplexity to
Verscell to Zillow to Cloudflare all
across our 110 episode catalog. The best
way for you to get to know our community
both online and offline is by
subscribing to the podcast and our
newsletter which you can find at the
roomodcast.com. Perkins Kuey supports
the most innovative entrepreneurs and
investors in fastmoving and high growth
sectors addressing their myriad of legal
needs. But the firm doesn't just provide
end-to-end legal and business counseling
to its startup clients. It also
facilitates introductions to key
adviserss and sources of capital.
Perkins Kuey's interactive website,
Startup Percolator, offers access to
programs, resources, and rich dynamic
content designed to assist entrepreneurs
on their startup journey. To learn more,
go to startup
percolator.com and
perkins ci.com.
This podcast is brought to you by
Mercury, the banking platform businesses
like the Room podcast used to simplify
their finances. It's time banking did
more than hold your money. Now it can.
With Mercury, you can pay bills in
seconds, close the books faster, and
even send invoices. Not only does
Mercury do away with a patchwork of
tools, it eliminates guesswork, giving
you complete and accurate visibility
into your business's finances, all from
one account. Apply in minutes at
mercury.com.
Welcome back to the room podcast. Today
we're thrilled to take you inside the
room with Alexa Gbel, co-founder and CEO
of Pocus. Pocus is redefining how sales
teams prospect leveraging AI agents to
automate the manual time-conuming parts
of sales research so reps can focus on
what they do best, selling. Since
launching out of Stanford's GSB, Alexa
and her co-founder have scaled Pocus to
support leading gotomarket teams at
companies like Canva, Asana, and
Monday.com. With backing from investors
like CO2, First Round, and Box Group,
Alexa's journey into tech wasn't linear.
She started her career in consulting
before heading to business school,
initially thinking she'd become a VC,
but a class project turned into a
company and she hasn't looked back
since. In this conversation, we dive
into the early days of Pocus, the
decision to build AI agents for sales
teams, not replace them, and the lessons
learned from scaling a B2B product in a
noisy, fast-moving market. Key topics in
this episode include building PLG tools
as a nonPLG founder, early go to market
hiring missteps, fundraising hot takes,
and the future of AI powered selling.
Madison and I were so energized by
Alexa's clarity and conviction. We know
you will be too. Let's open the door.
Alexa, thank you so much for being on
the Room podcast today. Thank you for
having me. I'm so excited. We are so
excited as well and we want to hear your
entire story. We love to start at the
beginning with our guests. Tell us where
did you grow up and how did that shape
your view of the world? I grew up right
outside of
Philadelphia. And when you ask this
question, it's very interesting because
I didn't think about this. I didn't put
two and two together where my mom was
actually super entrepreneurial, but I
wouldn't have thought of her as a tech
founder. She first started her physical
therapy practice, a very small, but
still from nothing. And then she
actually went on and started a small
consumer goods product. And so she was
always experimenting with different
ideas and trying new things and building
it literally with her hands. And at the
time, I didn't think anything of I just
thought she had fun experimenting with
new things. But now looking back, it
really did shape my ability to think,
okay, I can build something. I can do it
from scratch. I can try it. I really
appreciate that from my early childhood.
That's incredible. What was the product
that your mom built? It's no longer
around, but it's called Wappies. W R A P
E Z. It's stretch fabric reusable gift
wrap. So, she was always really
frustrated by wrapping gifts for us, so
she built it out of that. And it's cool
to just literally start with your hands
and build nothing. Build something from
nothing. It's incredible that you had
such an entrepreneurial role model as a
mom. Tell us when you were younger, did
you ever think you were going to become
a founder yourself? No. And I think
that's such a misconception if people
think that they just go to elementary,
middle, high school and think I'm going
to become a founder. I never thought
that. I didn't know what I wanted to do.
I actually didn't know I would become a
founder until I became a founder. I'd be
curious if it's the same for both of
you, but that's what it was for me. No,
I always joke that I always wanted to be
the first lady, not the president. Like
seemed like a cooler job. None of the
stress, but like the access and I feel
that way a little about being a founder
now with the podcast and people ask
about it and I'm like, "No, it wasn't
the goal, but I'm happy that I arrived
here." Totally. Just like a few natural
steps and you look back and you're like,
"Oh my gosh, I'm glad I just kind of
stumbled into this and didn't know what
I was getting myself into." Totally. And
I think that's really important to know,
right? Because sometimes life takes you
in different ways and there's one thing
that leads to the next to become a
founder. So you don't need to at the age
of 18 think you're going to be a founder
to become a founder. College and
education, I think it's such an integral
part into our early careers and how we
see the world. So let's dive into that a
little bit. For undergrad, you attended
Vanderbilt University. You studied
engineering there. Tell us about your
time at college and then how that led
you into your new grad years at KPMG. I
went to Vanderbilt not even really
knowing what engineering was. I just
loved math and physics in high school.
So I was thinking this probably makes
sense for me. And so once I got in there
I did love it. And I took some mostly
engineering classes, some business
classes. I didn't know what I wanted to
do. And so I after graduation did what
everyone else who doesn't know what to
do and went into consulting. And really
the reason being is I heard that
consulting is where you learn business.
And truly you do you learn how to be
customerf facing. You learn how to build
financial models. You learn how to
present good stories. And so very glad I
did it to learn those quote unquote
business fundamentals. But again it's
not like I woke up and said I'm going to
be an engineer or I'm going to go into
consulting. I went into engineering
because I liked math and I went into
consulting because I wanted to quote
unquote learn business. It's funny
because so many of our guests on the
podcast were management consultants and
really got a view of the world that way.
That's honestly quite interesting
because you wouldn't think that would be
such an entrepreneurial pipeline. I
think it's changed. I think for our
generation, yes, because that was the
where you go to learn business. I do
think for the future it's more of the
like product role at a startup or even
now a sales role at a startup is if I
were redoing it I would do that. And
then another thing that we see a lot is
people going to business school and then
starting companies after business school
in 2019 after years in the workforce you
attended Stanford's GSB. tell us why
business school before that after
consulting I went to a startup called
data minor and I was building out the
sales ops function and when I was there
I loved it it was awesome that's where I
really learned how to operate and build
and be in startups and what I saw though
throughout my entire career in even
engineering and then consulting and then
tech it was just so many men in
leadership positions and honestly I
never worked for a woman so I went to
business school again with this vague
concept of I want to become a female
executive and I want to maybe become a
VC because VCs can invest in female
founders and I can change the future for
women and so applied went there. Of
course, I didn't end up becoming a VC.
But I went for this grand vision of we
need to change the game for women in
tech and one hypothesis was by being a
venture capitalist, I can do that. While
you were at GSB, you did dip your toes
into investing. You founded the 21 fund.
Tell us more about that fund and how GSB
more broadly set you down that path into
saying, "Hey, I actually want to be in
the driver's seat. I want to be building
as a founder." I got to GSB and just I'd
say 90% of the people that go to GSB I
was like I'm going to be a VC and I did
all of the things to become a VC. I did
the fellowship with PIR which is
amazing. Everyone should do it. I did
MBA fund. I did everything you could
possibly do. I'm sorry I'm cracking up
because I was also doing the PAR
fellowship. Shout out Keith Bender. And
then also I'm starting the fund for my
year. Oh my gosh. I can't believe it it
went that long. That is so phenomenal.
It's crazy because so I'm not a GSB but
we don't have a strong history of doing
it at HBS and we've been talking I don't
know if you know staff who founded PIN
the platform for like crowdfunding for
investment clubs anyway. So we're using
a GSB founded company to run ours. Yeah
Steph and my husband started the 2020
fund. Shout out Leor Mushin is they're
the brains behind all of this. He
started the 2020 fund and then he handed
over the keys to myself and a few others
of here's the secret sauce and so we
started the 21 fund as well. Yeah, you
should check out Leor and his new VC
fund as well. The other crazy crossover
here is when we were raising our preede,
I think Leor was one of the first
investors I spoke to. I didn't even know
that. Which is Yeah. You know, like
pitch number three type of thing. So
that's truly crazy. go to GSB to start a
company and find your husband. That
would be really nice. We can talk about
that too. Good go to market strategy for
sure. I definitely feel like the fund
component of business school is
interesting just for the listeners who
aren't as familiar. It's like this
concept of unicorns are built every day
coming out of these great business
schools across the country. Let's always
invest in our peers and friends who are
starting companies. And our hope and our
belief by the numbers is that it will
have an outsized return for the fund. So
the LPS are actually our classmates and
I think this is like a really cool
access point and Alexa I'm curious to
hear how this shaped your story and your
ultimate path but of like in a very
lightweight way investing in the venture
ecosystem which is very illquid and
quite frankly usually very expensive to
get access to these funds. So it makes
it a bit more palatable and accessible
which I think is really encouraging
because I think that's one of the
hardest things about venture is you know
how hard it is to break in. Yeah, it was
phenomenal and I would do it again. It's
a way for both your classmates from the
investing side to be able to have a
piece of the pie and without spending
millions of dollars putting an
investment for $3,000 to have a part in
this and it's essentially an index fund
for your class. But then it's also very
valuable for the founder side. So we
probably invested in 40 founders of
which I guess I invested in myself as
well. So we're we're in a group chat
with each other. We support each other.
We ask each other questions. And then
also when you tap into your classmates
that are now LPs in your investment,
they're not just incentivized to help
from a we love you perspective and we're
peers, but literally from a financial
perspective, they're incentivized to
support. As a founder, it's often hard
to find community of peer founders. It's
often a lonely journey. So it's
incredible to see how that sort of
business school background having that
group chat really was a part of your
starting journey. And so let's talk
about starting Pocus. You had your idea
in business school. So tell us about
those early inception days and the
moment when you decided that you were
going to build your own business and go
down that path. Did all the VC stuff.
Realized I don't like investing. I love
building. I was just so jealous of all
of my classmates that were building
startups. And I realized coming from a
startup background where I was actually
building things in sales ops that I had
ideas. There were a lot of things in
sales ops that are fundamentally broken
and need to be improved. And so I went
into a class called Lean Launchpad. I
don't know if they have that at HBS, but
they take maybe 10 teams of students
across GSB as well as engineering school
with some thesis of hypotheses of what
could be a big business. So I met my
co-founder Isaac. He was in the
engineering side and joined Launchpad
with this hypothesis that sellers can be
more productive and there's ways to make
them even better if there were data from
all these siloed places combined
together. And that came from my sales
ops background. And so we spent probably
eight weeks uh ideulating on these ideas
and running series of experiments before
landing on the idea of what led us to
focus today towards the end of the
class. I'd love to talk more about
Isaac. It's so great that you found a
co-founder through the business school
experience. And I'm honestly having
these conversations with a lot of my
peers right now. Like we've done this in
this kind of sandbox space and we love
each other. We think we're both great
humans, but does this mean we should
start on what is likely a 10-year
journey? How did you guys broach those
conversations as you were coming out of
the Lean Launchpad moment? Yeah, we
actually did Lean Launchpad with four
people total and then just left the two
of us. We started just the two of us,
brought two others in and ended just us.
We were both co-founder dating, I like
to call it. We always joke he talked to
every single one of my five roommates
who were also looking for a co-founder
and I talked to all of his friends. So,
we literally both talked to 40 people in
the other person's class and what we
were both looking for is an idea that we
found very exciting and something that
could be 10x better than what exists
today. And then similar values and ways
that we wanted to build a company. And
so, a lot of the values we have today of
they were we use different words, but
being humble achievers, being really
smart, getting a lot of done, but
no ego or being a delusional optimist.
like we wanted to be a place where
people can have fun and think positively
and also we don't want to work a 9 to5.
We want to grind it out when we have to
and work really hard. And so we talked a
lot about those visions and values and
over time you have to start working with
someone and get in the weeds and see the
challenges that there's going to be
problems every day to actually figure
out. You can have the best friend in the
world and they could be an awful person
to work with. You really have to get in
there and figure it out. forcing those
hard conversations early and also
getting those reps in and actually
getting to the point of being like,
"Okay, I know all of your worst but also
best traits and we're gonna know how to
push through those moments and have the
difficult conversations to get to where
you guys were, which was postgraduation,
we're going to market with this
startup." So, I guess to use a step
back, focus is certainly redefining the
sales prospecting industry and you're
providing a suite of tools for go to
market and sales teams. We've mentioned
the term sales aux a few times already.
Could we just take a step back and and
explain what is pocus product and how
did you get there from an aha moment?
Since day one the reason pocus exists is
to supercharge sales reps. We want to
make a world where you can have the best
sales reps in the world being super
productive generated pipeline closing
deals now which didn't exist when we
started that can all be powered with AI.
So we can talk about that journey. But
what Pocus does is it's a collection of
all of these different AI agents that
are scraping both your internal data and
external data to do all that manual
tedious work of researching and
prospecting. So sales teams just have to
get alerted on specific things with
their accounts. They get alerted with
complete summaries of how they should
actually do their job and
recommendations for how they should
reach out to prospects and close deals.
So that's what we are today. There was
definitely a journey from the vision has
stayed the same but what our product has
looked like and the positioning from the
days of lean launchpad to now. My
understanding of the sales tech stack is
it's incredibly sticky, right? Because
once a team from a sales or puts you in
and it's working, you're closing more
deals. It's really exciting and you want
that product and tool to continue to
win. And you guys have managed to do
that with companies. We've actually
interviewed the Clockwise team, you
know, Asauna, Monday, Canva. These are
household brand names that are
leveraging your product to continue
building out their own business. How did
you get those first customers to say yes
to you? I LinkedIn DM'd a lot of a lot
of people um telling them, "Hey, I'm a
student at Stamford. Here's my idea. Can
I get feedback?" And Clockwise was
actually one of our first design
partners that we built with. So I pinged
one of their AES. I was like, "I want
some feedback." She gave us feedback. We
started meeting with her every week,
moving from Figma to actual product. And
then it moved to, okay, this looks like
something we'd want. So I connected with
Matt, the CEO, and got them onto the
product. And Matt actually became an
early angel investor of Pocus just
because we were working so closely
together. It's a little bit of brute
force. And Claudia, I'm sure you have a
similar experience of just reaching out,
begging people to give you feedback
until they're willing to try things out.
One thing that I realized the hard way
when we started building our initial
version of our product, which we since
had kind of pivoted away from, was when
you're working with a design partner,
you have to be really strategic about
how to get honest feedback. Because a
lot of people are really great at
saying, "Yeah, this is cool." But that
doesn't mean they're actually going to
pay or use the product. So, it sounds
like you and Matt and the Clockwise team
clearly had a really productive design
partnership. What advice would you have
for founders that are in that design
partnership phase? How do you get the
most out of working with a design
partner? Z was just telling me this how
it's really confusing because design
partners always tell you things are
great and then they don't want to pay.
And the reality is you're not going to
convert every design partner because
design partners usually have been
through hell with you through buggy
products, through just early iterations.
But you always have to be asking the
tough questions. And I found it helpful
to say, look, I'm asking as a founder,
not as a seller of this product. I
genuinely want to know what do you hate
about this? What do you wish you had?
What doesn't exist here? What is still
not working? And then the biggest test
is will you pay for this? And if it's
someone that's an IC, will are they
willing to go to their boss and fight
for this? Or if it's someone that's an
executive, do they see that this is
transformational to their business? So
design partners can have different
goals, right? You can be working with
one to build the product that they
actually want or you can be working
towards is this something that companies
will pay for. And so that clockwise it
was we were probably building with them
for a while before they paid. And I
think they they paid us nothing compared
to what our contracts are now. And so
they're they're still on that legacy
pricing, but that's just what design
partners are. Yeah. If I'm an AE, why do
I love Focus? AE is a couple things.
one, they're able to surface
opportunities they wouldn't have
identified before. And so last quarter
alone, we've generated half a billion in
pipeline for our customers. And so we're
actually able to surface this
information to them so that they know
that it's the right time to reach out to
a prospect. Another thing is call prep.
So when you have a meeting coming up,
we're able to give them all the insights
based on AI summarized research from
your internal data like CRM, a data
warehouse, call recording, email, as
well as external data like 10K's blog
post, podcasts to save them 10 plus
hours a week just digging through that
data. That's super helpful. Thank you.
because I think there's just such a
deluge of information and when your job
is to ultimately book new contract
revenue. Sometimes you don't know what
is the most valuable details and how
you're going to surface that. And it
sounds like the platform is empowering
people to do their job better with this
data management component. And one of
our favorite guests we've had on a few
times is actually the hightouch founder
Kashish Gupta and they're doing a lot.
And at the time when we had him on in
2022 was called the modern data stack. I
think it's shifted a bit on how we're
talking about it externally, but how
have you guys been part of that movement
of these tools that are helping power
data going from point A to point B? I
love the hightouch team. So, we're less
about moving data around, more about
surfacing insights that are relevant for
sellers. And so, I'll also say we're
less about replacing the sales rep's
job. We're more about supercharging
them. So what I mean by that is there's
a series of data that's sprawled
everywhere there. Usually a sales rep
has a million different tools open when
they have to just simply figure out who
should I reach out to and how do I win
this deal? And so for us by taking all
that data and surfacing it in a way
that's super relevant, super short and
sweet to the point giving them
everything they need in one cohesive
area. That's where we help. We're less
about what hight touch does of taking
data from one place and moving it to the
next. Absolutely. No, it's helpful to
hear about and just that distinction is
really useful. Thank you. And I guess
you could say it's like magic. Hocus
pocus. Yeah, a classic film and
definitely a really fun analogy. And
honestly, it's working. And from the
venture perspective, you've raised over
$20 million in a series A from Hallmark
venture firms from KTOU, First Round,
and Box Group. We're curious who was the
first person to say yes to investing in
Pocus. one of our professors at lean
launchpad who's a pair partner Mar she
actually approached us after the class
and said we want to give you this before
we had even a product and so we said we
were honored flattered flabbergasted and
then we said we want to build a product
before we raise a pre seed so then we
went back to her it was her and then I
think the first that we signed a term
sheet was box group though it was either
box group or pair around the two of them
and are you based in New York. I am I
was in SF at the time, but I recently
moved to New York. I hear about Box
Group a lot in the New York ecosystem.
So that that's great. Maybe just one
question for me before I pivot back to
Claude's is what's a fundraising hot
take that you have? I don't know if this
is a hot take, but keeping fundraising
as short as possible and you should
never be fundraising until you actually
have a term sheet. So making sure that
when you go out and start talking to
investors you can say especially for a
seed round which should move pretty
quickly because there's not much
diligence to do it should be I have a
term sheet I want this to move over the
next two weeks because I think the time
pressure and FOMO helps drive the round
incredibly helpful advice for folks that
are fundraising especially during this
time of year we've had a lot of folks on
the podcast give advice for just
fundraising more generally or getting
your first term term sheet at the seed
or preede. Pocus is an enterprise
startup. You're selling into other
businesses. Obviously had an incredibly
successful series A raise. What advice
would you have for B2B startup founders
raising their A? What metrics do you
think these funds are looking for?
There's similar things within every
raise. It's going to be you need a great
team, you need a great product, and you
need customer love and traction. The
actual metrics just change like as you
raise. I haven't raised a B yet, but I
imagine from those just the data element
becomes more in the weeds. For us, for
an A, traction is the most important
thing and that comes from customers. So,
I think more than anything, it's
actually customer love at the A of just
people that are obsessed. I will quit my
job if I don't have this. If you give a
customer a call, they will say, "This is
the best thing to ever happen to me in
my job." And then, of course, we raised
at a different time where funding was
much easier. But now you need to see
that month overmonth growth and more
important to see the consistent growth
versus the kind of AR metric in total.
Thank you for sharing that. Looking back
at kind of my journey as a founder, one
of the toughest things for me coming
from a product background and not having
had any experience in sales was how do
we build our sales team? How do we set
up our sales stack? What are our STRs
doing? Now it's like this fully
automated pipeline into Salesforce, so
on and so forth. But the sales landscape
has really changed a lot even since a
couple of years ago when I stood up my
sales team. AI has really changed sales
motions. It's completely changed how
SDRs are prospecting and finding
accounts. How did you think about
iterating on your own goto market
strategy and monetization plans in the
current AI context and maybe how that
has even impacted the Pocus product? Our
belief as a business is that AI can
supercharge sellers and all of their
jobs to be done. So everything from
prioritizing your target accounts to
doing the prospecting to taking notes to
updating CRM everything AI can really
help them do all that part of their job
where I don't think AI is yet is or as
interesting as fully replacing the
seller. And so how we've thought a lot
about it is where within our business
can we use AI ourselves to replace the
tedious manual work to free up our
sellers and to free up the broader go to
market team so that they can ultimately
have larger books and get more done
because they're spending less time doing
research and data digging and more time
talking to sellers. I think another
thing that has changed a lot related to
AI or more just related to the changes
in market is that sellers need to be way
more strategic and valuedriven. You
can't just go out there and spray and
prey and email everyone with the same
email and send mass outreach. It has to
be way more leading with a point of view
of hey I've saw that your business is
undergoing this transformation. This is
how we can help. And that actually in
itself led to one of our product
features called AI strategy which takes
all this information and then surfaces
up a POV for the seller or point of view
for the seller to break into an account
between AI freeing up the rep's time and
then the need for reps to be more
strategic that came from our own reps
doing the work and then we're able to
support other teams in doing it.
Totally. I remember when our sales team
was talking to me around like how do we
figure out how to better personalize our
emails? where do we go to research all
this stuff? Do we just Google the
company? And it was like, yeah, I guess.
But now with Pocus, they get those
insights right away. Cool. So, we
chatted a little bit about the sales
teams themselves. What goes wrong when
founders try to build their initial go
to market team? Everything. If you're a
first time, if you're a second time
founder, I think you can learn a lot.
But I have yet to meet a first-time
founder that isn't secretly behind
closed doors saying I've done everything
wrong in my go to market team. Like
engineering is way more straightforward.
There's a product to build a new product
and you and you build it. With go to
